comments.text: If you look closely at the profile pic of this model, you can see the top is missing - the thumb hides it. This is because the slicing program will make a gap just under the top of the tower. The printer will try to print the top into thin air, and will fail - as seen in the profile pic above. Also notice that the railing is missing in this pic - also too thin. Should have a warning about this in the description, should have an honest picture, and should not have 8000 likes.

comments.text: The railing is too thin to be considered printable by most slicers.  Even on high resolution mode, the railing is not there in Simplfy3D.  I played around with this model and discovered that by scaling the Z axis to 150 mm, (124.02%), the railing is there.  I have printed other things 150 mm tall, but that is close to the limit for my printer.  Hopefully this discovery helps someone else as well.

title: GARRETT ATX END CAP SCUFF GUARD

description.text:
Working in tidal pools and amongst rocks with my new GARRETT ATX inspired me to created some protection on the rear end for this hardy machine.
This scuff guard is designed to protect the back end of the Garrett ATX. It covers the speaker and has holes for the on/off switch and the head phone connector. Both can be used with the scuff guard in place. The scuff guard sits tightly in place so does not require any further fastening.

Further work may be to put mounts on for a sling attachment which I am thinking about. I've included the Inventor ipt file should you wish to make changes like creating slots for the speaker. I haven't, because I'd like to keep as much grime out of the speaker as possible.
All files are included for 3D printing, you can use either the .stl or .thing files. Printed perfectly in one go on the Makerbot Replicator 2. Maybe somebody could try in ABS

Anti-Wobble TR8x2

comments.text:
Well, I found my head shaking so much it would not print. My solution was to make a Nylon nut to replace brass nut. Brass is not a good bearing/wear part. They should have been made from Bronze. Brass is an alloy of copper and zinc. Bronze is an alloy of copper and Tin.
Zinc is not a good wear material. I took a piece of nylon and made outside shape of nut. Then I took my threaded rod and put some slots around outside of it for clearance of nylon shavings. Oh yes there is 2-3 inches extra length on rod for my MB rep 2. I think you should put Nylon in lathe and rod in chuck. Then turn lathe by hand and apply pressure and use rod like a tap. Go in 1-2 turns at a time. No lube is necessary because Nylon is a good bearing material. Yes I asked Maker Bot why they used Brass for nut and the answer was "no understand". I would like to make a mold for this Nylon nut.I have seen molds made with one thread on core and cavity to make complete thread in hole. Yes I love to figure out things like this. I have some molding machines and tool shop to make molds like this. When I learn to program 3-D prints, I'll have it made. kwg

title: Turbine 2.0
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Some Ideas around the ingenious Turbine Thing of RichMac http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:76369
Stator and Turbinewheel are identical. The Shaft bearing in the Front is an 8x15x5 so only the original shaft needs an appropriate extension.
The housing parts are identical from their functional inner dimensions. I increased the outer diameter of the front part to get more wallthickness in the area of the thread - this was a weak area of my prints.... some parts are broken only by internal material tension. I splitted the front part (for glueing) because to print in one peace is difficult... 05/20/2013
....added an Idea for an 2-Way-Adapter/Handler - one side for the vacuum (cleaner) and the other side to simply plug in the Turbine.
(Turbine may be thightend with an O-Ring around the rear of the Turbine and thightens by the vacuum)
... tested it out today - simply plug the Turbine and my Vacc-Cleaner..... works great :) further redesign is in work :)

description.text:
You can print light portable yagi components.
The boom is 25 mm PVC or Al pipe.
Elements are 3.2 mm Al welding rods. Reflector for 2m antenna is divided to 2 parts. Is longer than 1m and is connected with screw terminal.
Radiator is 4mm brass welding rod.

You can build any antenna from http://www.qsl.net/dk7zb/PVC-Yagis/PVC-details.htm

You can buy 3D printed components here:
http://hamshop.cz/antennas-c9/portable-yagi-antenna-components-kit-i301/

Print from ABS or PLA.
Radiator holder with support and other parts without support.

You can modify openscad files for your dimensions.

comments.author: kerog777

description.text: This a dragon thats going to eat a fish

The Infinite Sand Castle

This is my entry for the Build a Castle challenge!

The main goal in designing these moulds was to show how tessellation can create complex patterns from simple shapes. I was inspired by the Islamic mosaics from the Alhambra and created a simplified pattern that could work as the floor plans for the sand castle. The moulds were modelled in Blender, sliced in Cura, and printed on a BQ Hephestos Prusa i3.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N37bd8Xsngs

The moulds are already scaled correctly and can be printed in most 3D printers. It is important that the moulds are solid so that they will not break, so the this walls must be completely filled. You can either set the filling to 100% for the entire mould or increase the number of shells (or shell thickness) to ensure that no gaps are left between the thin walls. The layer height can be set quite high, since we're not looking for fine detail. The settings I used in Cura (for a 0.4mm nozzle) are the following:

  • Layer Height: 0.3mm
  • Shell Thickness: 3.4mm
  • Fill Density: 60%
  • Print Speed: 60mm/s

comments.text: I'll definitely print them next summer for my kids :)

description.text:
Based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:41967 but set up to use a leadscrew instead of threaded rod and nuts.

The other side is at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:912614

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/a2UxYM7jKWW

If you're doing your own export from TinkerCad, I'd highly recommend running it through https://modelrepair.azurewebsites.net/ - TinkerCad produces some slightly questionable STLs when there's intersecting geometry in an imported model, causing slic3r to sometimes lose pieces of the model.

This is a simple remix of BattleShots by fluetke - all credits go to him!

This is a version of BattleShot which holds Beerbottles/cans instead of shots and makes for a very fun and very hardcore drinking game!
It was made as a festival game and was a huge succes during the
I higly recommend two teams of 3 or 4 teammembers each.

It takes a very very long time to print (largest ship is 80cm long!), but it is hilarious and a great party game!
The version is simply doubled in size and sliced into smaller pieces to be able to fit my printbed :-)
Afterwards pieces are glued together using superglue, and a 3Doodler in the corresponding colors for extra strength.

Printed @210c with layerhight @0.32mm (1st layer @75%) with heated bed.
Infill @10% for fast printing, but I suggest 20-25% for better structural integrity

Board consists of two 8x8 grid of 16.5cm squares along with a smaller 8x8 4cm grid painted onto a tarpaulin (see picture for sketch)

Both boards were placed in two canopies separatedby a canopy-side halfway down, to cover the players ships, but still being able to talk to eachother.

I suggest using the phonetic alphabet since this makes it much easier and a bit more "realistic" ;-)

A: Alfa
B: Bravo
C: Charlie
D: Delta
E: Echo
F: Foxtrot
G: Golf
H: Hotel

title: Laptop cooler cleaner module for vacuum cleaner

description.text:
Did you ever need simple module to clean your laptop without complex opening and closing it ?
There is an module that is simple attachment for any vacuum cleaner.
Try cleaning your laptop once per month and you will see performance impact.

Inner dimensions of the box is 80x16.5x19.5 mm enough to cover most of the laptop coolers.
Longest side is 40mm and its functions is to be bottom limiter and for some laptop coolers closer of bottom holes near cooler.
Vacuum cleaner hose inner diameter is 31.5 mm.
It is protected with some electric tape to prevent layer separation due inside pressure of hose.

Print material: PLA
Print temp: 195 C
Layer thickness: 0.2
Nr. of shells: 2
Infill percent: 30%
Slicer: CuraEngine
Speed: 35 mm/s print speed, 30 mm/s outer perimeter, 80 mm/s infill
Printer: Kossel Delta
Printed horizontally, long side to bed, without support.

author: mbasov

description.text: I needed to layout full strings for a project so I extended donb's wonderful DraFont library. This version will dump all ascii characters from a font by default, and provide a method for laying out strings. For the brave, there is a git repo at https://github.com/pipakin/OpenSCAD-Font-Importer (This is not for the faint of heart, my python skills are substandard at best) NOTE: Complicated glyphs can take a long time to render, and I've managed to crash OpenSCAD a LOT by using long strings. For example, "FONTZ!" takes 1 minute 30 seconds to render, while "This is a test string." takes significantly longer (on the order of 13 minutes). So if you are going to use this for something, I recommend generating your string, rendering it, and then outputting an STL to use in your design with import_stl. UPDATE: Removed the arial font (forgot about licensing), and substituted FreeSerif

Prerequisites:
  • Python
  • Freetype (2.4.4)
  • Freetype-py
    • USAGE: python full_ddump -f [font file] -o [output file] -m [module name] Optional Parameters:
    --strings [name of strings file] (default none)
    --size [size of characters] (default 12)
    --height [z height of characters] (default 10)
    --startcode [hex unicode value to start at] (default 021)
    --endcode [hex unicode value to end at] (default 07E) Your scad file must include the produced scad. The produced scad references the font_base.scad file, so you'll need it too.
    example: include <FreeSerif.scad> To render a letter, you call the module with that letter (or ordinal)
    Example: FreeSerif("S"); or FreeSerif("0x41"); or FreeSerif(65); To use string layouts, you have to provide a string file. This file is a list of strings (separated by newlines). To use a string, it must match this file exactly. Then you can call the module with those strings.
    Example: FreeSerif("FONTZ!");

This is a customization of Jörg Sprave's "Rambone" slingshot design. It's main feature is the addition of a 357 Ruger type grip for the handle and for my purposes I removed the holes and opted for using a set of slanted grooves to hold the elastic in place.

Original Design: http://www.theslingshotforum.com/f9/rambone-files-31731/

BTW a slingshot in Afrikaans (South Africa) is called a "Kettie"

Printed with normal PLA with a 50% infill and shell setting at 5 seems to be enough to make this slingshot extremely tough and hard to break. You can however print it solid for extra strength.

title: Mini Plastic Dryer for Filament Extruder

description.text:
This is first version, I did it after having some problems with filament made from Filament Extruder of my (designed by Sr. Hugh Lyman)
My goals: It solves two major problems (in my opinion):

  1. Extrusion speed of filament is too slow (about <20”/per minute).
  2. Water bubbles exist in filament fiber (plastic pellets is always moist water ,slightly wet)
    The second reason makes bubbles on fiber, it appears on: extruding high speed or high temperature (from 190°C to 195°C). Can not extrusion high speed while using low temperatures: about 175°C -185°C, this case I called unripe extrusion, Plastic fibers are hard, slightly grainy if we look carefully. (Plastic tested: ABS, TPU)

Results after drying:

  • Extrusion speed has increased, in my extruder machine is > 60”/per minute (maximum in my extruder, I think that there may be higher)
  • Filament fiber: slick, smooth and especially no bubbles.

An important, all thing above is only my personal opinion, I hope and I will listen to the opinions of people, thanks.

Below is detailed of the mini dryer :
. Heat band: 250w, Φ30mm x L. 60mm
. Drying temperature: 100-125°C
. Drying time: 30’-45’
. Capacity: 1 kg plastic
. Dimension: W.150mm x L.160mm x H.300mm
Cost about: 100usd

Video link:
https://youtu.be/63xcl10QMIM
I hope it will be useful for someone

By: Thong NguyetViet
Please view details in PDF document and Video

title: Customizable Nylon Clothes Closet Rod Linking Bracket

description.text:
Don’t you hate the way your closet’s clothes hanging rod dips in the middle? How your longest garments sweep the floor or cover your shoes? Well, I did; but now I’ve fixed it.

This part was designed to be printed in Nylon 618 (or similar) material. When installed it should be twisted into place so the material fibers are working in their strongest orientation.

Printing in Nylon on a consumer 3D printer can be difficult. I've had greatest success by following the following steps:

  1. Slice the model with raft and supports and parameters suitable for printing in Nylon (temperature=245C, etc.)
  2. Use blue painters tape on the build platform
  3. Add a layer of undiluted Elmer's glue
  4. Print the raft directly into the glue, pause print
  5. Wait for the glue to dry completely
  6. Resume print

author: greenfirstflash

description.text:
Name tag with nat
on it

This is a semi-permanent belt for the ABP. It is a derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7460 by tmartin. Tmartin uses titanium, which would be preferable, but is not widely available in the dimensions needed.
Use steel foil measuring 12" width by .002" thick, you'll need to cut the roll at the final belt width.
I used some steel foil from the local electronics store (Elliots in tucson) where they charged me $1/ft, but this stuff is available from many locations: http://www.mcmaster.com/#stainless-steel-foil/=cntox8
http://cgi.ebay.com/NEW-K-S-Stainless-Steel-002-Foil-6030-NIB-/290545521747?pt=Radio_Control_Parts_Accessories&hash=item43a5dcd453#ht_739wt_905
http://www.quickshipmetals.com/foils/stainless-foil-00212.html Apparently this foil is used for "tool-wrapping" whatever that is... Steel is a great belt medium because: (borrowed from tmartin)
1) Unlike aluminum foil and paper, it does not normally crinkle and maintains a smooth flat shiny surface unless deliberately creased. It it actually somewhat springy.
2) It is flexible like a sheet of paper and rolls smoothly through the mechanism
3) The coefficient of thermal expansion is much lower than plastic over the temperature ranges used, therefore although the plastic will adhere nicely when hot, when both are cooled the plastic shrinks more than the surface beneath it and pops right off.
4) It is physically extremely tough and will survive a lot of abuse.
5) Not damaged by build platform temperatures.
6) Inexpensive.
7) Great for raftless printing
8) Excellent thermal conductivity, gets hot all over. Disadvantages:
1) It is NOT chemically inert and will not withstand solvent attack.
2) There will be a seam on the belt which will occasionally leave a (small) line on the bottom of a print
3) Poor adhesion to ABS, must be coated with Kapton tape. Sanding doesn't help.
4) Steel may crease if you are not careful when making the belt.
5) Cannot run the ABP conveyor backwards (as if you would want to)
6) Steel may swell when heated causing a loss of belt tension. Note: I noticed that the belt works even better and stays even flatter when I added the new countersunk plate to my ABP. This provides just a bit of an edge that the belt must wrap over on the front and back. Plus no more bolt interference. See the pic!

1) Remove your previous belt and cut it open to form a single, flat strip.
2) Build your belt tool which can be used to create more belts of perfect size.
a. Find a stiff cardboard tube (Dougc314 recommends 3" PVC)
b. Wrap 3 strips of duct tape around cardboard tube until you approach correct belt circumference.
c. Finish wrapping with clear packing tape until the plastic belt fits tightly around the tape and edges line up
d. Tool is done (see photo)
3) Using a straight edge and razor blade (on an ugly wood surface) cut a strip of foil from top to bottom. Make the strip slightly narrower than the plastic belt in order to avoid interfering with the bolt heads on the ABP. I first used scissors to cut the strip, but found that it left my edge rippled, which may interfere with prints later on. A razor will leave a flat edge. Your strip should be about 4" x 12"
4) Wrap the strip carefully around the belt tool. Make sure the outer edges line up perfectly and that you have about 1/2" of seam overlap.
5) Tape the seam so the belt is nice and tight on the tool.
6) Wrap Kapton over the metal at a sharp diagonal angle (wider kapton won't require a diagonal.) Make sure to overlap onto the bare packing tape on the sides, this will be trimmed in the next step. When wrapping the Kapton, try to reduce the seams by lining the kapton up carefully with the previous wrap. The tape should be sprialing around your tool leaving small seams between each wrap. Better seams = better prints.
7) With a razor, cut through the tape along the edges of the new belt and pull off the excess Kapton.
8) Slide your belt off the tool. This may be tricky if you made the belt too tight.
9) The new belt should look much like the stock belt. The main difference is the loose flap on the inside of the belt. DO NOT TAPE THIS DOWN. Leaving it loose will allow the belt to slide over the rollers more easily.
10) When mounting on the ABP, make sure this flap is on the top side and pointing towards the rear of the machine. This will keep it from getting caught under the drive rollers. Never run the ABP backwards or this flap may slide behind a roller and ruin the belt. UPDATE 6-20
I've had some success cutting off the inside flap of the belt. If you cut it off completely so that the two edges of the foil are flush, you can kapton-tape over it and have a flap-free belt.
Also, some users have noted that they would like the belt to be tighter. If you want your belt tighter, just use less tape layers on the belt tool. Be careful though, if you go too tight, you will crease the new belt on the drive support nubs when installing it. (this happened to me)

comments.text: Well, so far anything over .002 thick is too stiff and won't go around the driveing shafts.  .002 is nice, I get the best results with .0015.  .001 just wrinkles too much and easily.  So it looks like .0015 or .002 are best choices.
comments.author: scootnfast

comments.text: I got a scrap of 3" ABS pipe from the hardware store, wrapped in 3 layers of duct tape and 1 layer of clear packing tape, and the fit is just about perfect.
comments.author: tlrobinson

comments.text: This is great. Best belt I've made thus far. But just a little loose. I need to remove a layer or two of duct tape on my tool.
comments.author: mkellner

comments.text: I built this using stainless steel foil, from Mcmaster Carr, .002 inch. I wrapped it with 1 inch Kapton tape, at an angle. I found that 3 inch PVC pipe, which is 3.5 inches OD is almost the right diameter, just a bit small. I wrapped the with about 12-15 layers packing tape untill the spare plastic belt was tight, then made the steel belt. In hindsight I think using standard letter size sheets of paper would make a better diameter increaser. Also I would leave it a little loose on the plastic belt, so as to make the steel belt tighter. Mine is a bit too loose, it's usable but would be better tighter (it lifts off the platform too much).  The printed ABS sticks very well to the Kapton.  In the photo, you can see a small part I printed. I could use that part as a handle and move the build platform in X and Y (motors off of course). You can also see I didn't do such a great job wrapping it at an angle, wide tape would certainly make tha wrapping job easier.
comments.author: dougc314

comments.text: Say, get a small drill bit and counter sink the bolt holes. Install flat head screws. Enjoy going headless on the build platform. I did. It is a lot safer - for the Hot End.

author: PropsFactory

description.text:
I needed a threading dial for my Emco Maximat Super 11 metal lathe but they are very hard to come by so I decided to design and print one.

My machine is the imperial version so I only needed a single 16 tooth gear instead of the 3 gear version on the metric machines. I found some dimensions online which helped get a rough idea and then 2 prototypes and I had a working version.

Ive used this for a few threading operations now and it works as it should tracking screw position.

I printed this on an Up! Plus 2 with all 3 pieces orientated along the Z axis to keep the shaft and shaft holes as accurate as possible.

I used 0.15mm layers with a 75% fill for the body and 95% fill for the gear/shaft combo and dial.
